Insertion sort method 1, New array which takes in a list and sorts it by creating a new array and inputting elements 1 by 1 each item with a helper function "add" placed until the given array is empty

---

The time complexity is O($n^2$)

#Insertion Sort Method 2 (Shifting)
def shift(array, index): #Helper method for insertion_sort_2
  s_index = 0 #swap index
  for i in range(index): #position goes (0,...,|i,...) for sorted and unsorted
    if array[i] < array[i]:
      s_index += 1
  array.insert(s_index, array.pop(index))

def insertionSort(array):
  for i in range(len(array)): #sorts through each index of the array with the shift function
    shift(array, i)
  return array

Insertion sort method 2, Takes an array and swaps items within the array by index, starting from the first with the shift helper function

---

The time complexity is O($n^2$)

Arr = ([], [7, 7, 7, 7], [5, 4, 3, 2, 1])
Expected = ([], [7, 7, 7, 7], [1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
for arr, exp in zip(Arr, Expected):
  insert_sorted = insertionSort(arr)
  print(f"insertion_sort_method2({arr}) = {insert_sorted}, expected = {exp}: sorted == exp -> {insert_sorted == exp}")

This recursive function takes in a list and recursively calls itself with 2 arrays half the length of the original, it them sorts these from the ground up using the merge helper function to merge the 2 sorted lists, sorting them before they go up the next level to be sorted again with a newly sorted list

The time complexity if O($nlog(n)$)
